column4: Title
column5: Abstract/Description
column12: Related concepts

column4: Improving land governance – for the sake of the rural poor
column5: Land and associated property is a major source of individuals’ identity and livelihood. The way in which land rights are assigned and can be used is a key determinant of equality of opportunity, environmental sustainability, social/economic transformation, and the ease and extent of public service provision. This article discusses why land rights are important but often only weakly protected and describes how recent technological developments make public efforts to secure such rights much easier – with tangible impacts for rural development.

column4: Why property rights matter
column5: It is widely accepted among economists and policy-makers that secure and well-defined land property rights are integral to poverty alleviation and economic prosperity. But how do legal systems, land tenure and economic development really relate to one another? Our author demonstrates the links using her latest research results from 146 countries.
column12: property rights; land rights; land policies; poverty; land tenure systems; sustainable development

column4: Land governance in German development cooperation
column5: Access to land is key to achieving food security, poverty alleviation, social equity and environmental protection. A brief insight in land governance-related principles and policies of the German development assistance.
column6: Felix Schilling; Jana Arnold; Jorge Espinoza
column12: land governance; land access; food security; poverty; environment; land policies; sustainable development

column4: Land reform – the solution to rural poverty?
column5: Following the end of apartheid, South Africa’s government set itself ambitious goals with a planned land reform. However, there have since been barely any changes in the country’s agricultural structure, and the positive impacts that were hoped for on rural livelihoods have hardly materialised. A critical assessment of 22 years of land reform policies.
column7: Institute for Poverty, Land and Agrarian Studies
column12: land reform; poverty; land policies; land law; agrarian structure; agriculture; rural population; rural development; land governance
column14: Access to Land & Tenure Security; Land Policy & Legislation

column4: What about the land rights of communities and Indigenous Peoples?
column5: Indigenous Peoples and local communities hold a large share of the world’s land area under customary systems. However, there is a tremendous gap between what is held by communities in practice and what is formally recognised by governments.
column12: indigenous peoples; indigenous land rights; local community; customary tenure; land tenure systems; illegal occupation

column4: Tanzania’s Village Land Act 15 years on
column5: The year 2016 marks 15 years since the new wave land reforms became operational in Tanzania. Despite its ambitious goals – encouraging land registration and titling, and empowering women and other vulnerable groups – the results are disillusioning. A brief overview of 15 years of implementation, using the Village Land Act as a case study.
column12: land reform; land rights; land policies; land registration; land titling; title deed; women; land law; land governance; land administration
column13: Land & Gender; Indigenous & Community Land Rights
column14: Land Policy & Legislation; Access to Land & Tenure Security

column4: Cambodia: Land grabs and rural dispossession by government design
column5: The land reform process in Cambodia is full of examples of injustice and human rights violations. Promises to improve the situation of the landless and land-poor citizens have remained unfulfilled. Development co-operation efforts have not changed this either.
column12: land reform; land policies; land rights; landlessness; poverty; sustainable development; development; development agencies

column4: No food security without land tenure security?
column5: Secure tenure of farming and forest land is increasingly recognised as an important factor of household food security and nutritional status. This is borne out by a study by the Laotian Land Issues Working Group. It demonstrates mutual impacts, how government land-related policies affect the factors involved, and who the winners and losers are.
column12: security of tenure (land); farming systems; forest land; food security; land policies; land tenure systems; land governance

column4: Those in darkness drop from sight
column5: Sierra Leone is one of the least developed countries in the world and is still recovering from a civil war that ended in 2002. Increasingly, the Sierra Leonean government seeks to attract foreign investors through providing opportunities for large-scale land leases for the development of agribusiness. This has triggered a rapid transformation process that poses a considerable threat to food security and social stability. Despite being a pilot country for the implementation of the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure, there is no real change on the ground as yet.
column12: land conflicts; land governance; land investments; land deals; food security; development agencies; sustainable development
column13: Land Conflicts; Land & Investments; Land Stakeholders & Institutions

column4: Net impacts of large-scale land acquisitions
column5: The buying up of farmland by international investors is viewed highly critically. However, sweeping judgements could be inappropriate, as our author demonstrates with survey results from Ethiopia and Uganda.
column12: farmland; land investments; land deals; land governance

column4: Securing pastoralists’ land tenure rights
column5: Formal land titles are rare in pastoral communities around the world. In the past, this presented hardly any problems, since pastoral land was seen as of little use by most outsiders. But with growing competition for areas legal uncertainty is becoming an increasing threat to the livelihoods of pastoralists.
column6:
Margherita Gomarasca;
Cornelia Heine; Andreas Jenet
column12: land titling; pastoralists; pastoral land rights; grazing; land dispute; land tenure systems; land governance

column4: Negotiating fair settlements
column5: Marked power imbalances often result in communities losing out in use conflicts over their territories and resources. This applies in particular to extractive industries and infrastructure projects. Community protocols can help bring the negotiating parties together at eye level and create a balance of interests.
column6: Stella James; Johanna von Braun; Gino Cocchiaro
column12: local community; land conflicts; extractive industries; land dispute resolution; land governance

column4: Making the SDGs count for land rights
column5: Does the inclusion of land rights in the global development agenda bear the potential to promote the secure and fair distribution of land rights? Yes, our author believes – provided that the land-rights community does not rest on its laurels and really addresses the crucial aspects.
column12: land rights; development agencies; sustainable development

column4: “We can‘t be satisfied yet“
column5: On the 11th May 2012, the Committee on World Food Security of the United Nations adopted the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests (VGGT). Rural 21 asked Roman Herre of the human rights organisation FIAN about his views on the implementation of the Guidelines so far.
column12: food security; development agencies; land rights; land policies; land governance; security of tenure (land); land tenure systems
column14: Access to Land & Tenure Security; Land Policy & Legislation

column4: Organic equals conventional
column5: In a long-term project in Kenya, the Swiss-based Research Institute of Organic Agriculture has examined the potential of organic and conventional agriculture regarding soil fertility, the occurrence of pests and diseases, and profitability. Initial results make a strong case to implement policy measures necessary for supporting the adoption of organic management practices on a large scale.
column12: development agencies; land governance; agriculture; agricultural land management; farming systems; farmers; land policies; land management

column4: At the wooden cross-road
column5: Fuelwood and charcoal continue to be indispensable in cooking the daily meal for most people in sub-Saharan Africa; in addition, wood as a fuel represents an important source of income. Pressure on forest resources as well as health hazards through indoor air pollution have resulted in more calls for switching to alternative energy sources. Our authors suggest another alternative: improving the existing supply chains.
column6: Harry Hoffmann; Michael Brüntrup; Klas Sander
column12: forest land; forest conservation; sustainable land management; environment
column13: Forest Tenure; Land, Climate change & Environment

column4: Strengthening family farms: a path to follow in combatting poverty in Africa
column5: A project in Burkina Faso has given a clear demonstration of what supporting family farms can achieve in terms of poverty alleviation and rural development. One important success factor was the transfer of land to farmers, accompanied by a secure land-tenure policy adapted to their needs.
column12: farming systems; farmers; poverty; rural development; land transfers; security of tenure (land); land tenure systems; land policies; land governance
column14: Access to Land & Tenure Security; Land Policy & Legislation

column4: Snakebite brings social and financial burden among Indian farmers
column5: Snakebites are a crucial, yet underreported issue in many South Asian countries. In India, they kill some 50,000 people every year. However, the government has neglected the issue. Now, it’s time to seriously address this all but forgotten public health problem, our author maintains.
column12: farmers; farming systems; rural development

column4: The Post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals: a historic opportunity
column5: In September 2015, the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are to be adopted in the context of the Post-2015 Agenda. In what way do the SDGs differ from the Millennium Development Goals? What does the community of states expect from their introduction? Our authors describe the background of the process and the latest developments in the debate.
column7: New York University - Center on International Cooperation
column12: development agencies; development

column4: Food and nutrition security in the SDGs – where are we heading?
column5: The demand to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger has been the centrepiece of the Millennium Development Goals; the first MDG stands for the inextricable link between poverty and people’s ability to access safe, nutritious and sufficient food. How will the objective of achieving global food and nutrition security be embedded in the SDGs? Will the SDGs be a further step towards this target?
column12: food security; poverty; development agencies; development; sustainable development
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land & Food Security

column4: An ambitious post-2015 development agenda will depend on soils
column5: The sustainable management of soils is crucial to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. This is evidenced by the analysis of the role soils play across the proposed agenda. However, some key aspects have not been sufficiently considered so far. Moreover, the SDGs will place increased demand on soils. Further advocacy is therefore needed to ensure that important soil and land related issues remain in the final declaration of the post-2015 agenda.
column6: Dr Jes Weigelt; Ivonne Lobos Alva
column12: sustainable land management; farming systems; farmers; food security; development; development agencies; sustainable development

column4: Monitoring progress on agriculture and rural development
column5: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) will amount to little unless backed by reliable indicators. Only with good metrics can the agenda be implemented and progress measured. Just like the SDGs themselves, the indicators are still in the discussion phase, with the Sustainable Development Solutions Network (SDSN) one of the many players in this process. They outline their recommendations in the following article, using rural development as an example to describe them.
column12: rural development; agriculture; agricultural land management; development; development agencies; sustainable development

column4: The SDGs – a paradigm shift towards more equality
column5: The Sustainable Development Goals differ radically from the current Millennium Development Goals in many aspects. Our author demonstrates the challenges that departing from a donor-oriented development framework poses – particularly for the North, and also with a view to its own development.
column12: development; development agencies; sustainable development

column4: “One World – No Hunger” A look at the German Development Ministry’s Initiative
column5: With reference to the “One World – No Hunger” Initiative, Stefan Schmitz shows how food policies can support the attainment of the Sustainable Development Goals and highlights the interdependencies between the individual goals and targets.
column12: food security; sustainable development; development agencies
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land & Food Security

column4: SDGs: Better process, worse outcome
column5: Meant well doesn’t always mean done well. The Sustainable Development Goals are all set to undermine themselves, Stephan Klasen maintains. The worst aspect is that people, who really ought to be at the focus, threaten to fall by the wayside in this technocratic maze of hundreds of goals, targets, and indicators.
column12: sustainable development; poverty; indigenous peoples; women; development agencies

column4: Nature as a commodity, or: Does nature have a value?
column5: Is it right to attach financial values to nature and to incorporate that valuation into the post-2015 agenda? Will such valuation help to protect species diversity and ecosystems? Or does it not rather harbour the risk that we cheerfully go on destroying nature since other aspects of the national accounts can be seen as compensation? Civil society is split on this issue. Our author points out why.
column12: land valuation; sustainable land management; development; sustainable development; development agencies; environment
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land, Climate change & Environment

column4: Climate change, environment and migration in the Sahel
column5: In the debate on climate change, it is frequently argued that the number of “climate refugees” is going to grow world-wide. So far, however, only little evidence has been provided of links between climate change, environmental changes and migration. The transdisciplinary research project “micle”– migration, climate & environment – has examined this link in selected areas of the Sahel zone.
column12: climate change; environment; displacement; sustainable development
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land, Climate change & Environment

column4: Fitter and healthier with traditional varieties
column5: In Kenya, smallholders are improving the health of their families by growing local cereal varieties and indigenous vegetables. The use of traditional foods is even helping people with HIV/AIDS.
column12: farmers; farming systems; rural development; sustainable development

column4: Simple technology, big impact
column5: More than 30 years ago, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) started a post-harvest programme in Central America named “Postcosecha”. The significant impact that was still evident long after the project end also continues to exist after the cessation of external support. The current priority in SDC’s contribution to post-harvest management (PHM) is to use existing knowledge and experience to create conditions for scaling up the most appropriate PHM technologies in sub-Saharan Africa.
column7: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation
column12: farming systems; development agencies; farmers; agricultural land management; sustainable development

column4: Reducing child labour in agriculture through agricultural projects
column5: According to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), a large share of child labour takes place in family-based agriculture. However, most agricultural projects do not address child labour, even though they have the potential to contribute to its prevention and reduction. Raising awareness about project impacts on child labour and the inclusion of child labour issues in the planning, monitoring and evaluation process of agricultural projects is one promising way to tackle child labour in agriculture, as emonstrated by a study in Cambodia.
column6: Heidi Feldt; Elen Ambros; Lena Bullerdieck; Robin Cordes; Leonie Craes
column12: agriculture; agricultural land management; farmers; youth; sustainable development

column4: Sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture: a key to food security and poverty alleviation
column5: Fishery plays a crucial role in poverty and hunger alleviation. It is therefore all the more important to secure the long-term conservation of fish stocks as a natural resource and to ensure fair access to them.
column12: fisheries; sustainable land management; farmers; food security; poverty; rural development; natural resources management; sustainable development
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land & Food Security

column4: Sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture: a huge challenge for development cooperation
column5: The global demand for fish and fish products is continuously increasing. However, fisheries management is still insufficient, leading to over-exploitation, illegal fishing and massive post-harvest losses. Our authors describe what has to be done.
column6: Dr Mark Prein; Dr Mecki Kronen; Kai Wiegler
column12: aquaculture; sustainable land management; fisheries; farmers; natural resources management; sustainable development

column4: Can aquaculture help the hungry poor?
column5: Aquaculture holds a big potential to satisfy the growing demand for aquatic food. Setting out from lessons learnt in past development projects, our author describes what fish farming systems must look like to fit the needs of smallholders and the environment.
column12: aquaculture; food security; poverty; sustainable development; development agencies; development; farmers; farming systems

column4: Towards sustainable tuna fisheries in the Philippines
column5: A project run by the WWF has set itself the goal of transforming Philippine tuna fisheries towards more sustainable practices, securing the livelihoods of the small-scale fishers in the long term. European buyers who have committed to source from them provide the necessary incentives.
column12: fisheries; aquaculture; farming systems; farmers; agricultural land management; natural resources management; sustainable land management

column4: Building confidence in certified seafood: the GSSI
column5: The multitude of certification schemes in seafood production has assumed massive dimensions, posing considerable challenges for all actors in the supply chain. Here, the Global Sustainable Seafood Initiative seeks to provide a remedy.
column12: fisheries; aquaculture; development agencies; natural resources management; sustainable land management

column4: Group certification: the silver bullet for smallholders?
column5: Often with just one or two ponds managed by a single person or family, smallholders make up an important share of the world’s seafood production. So why are by far the minority of certified aquaculture operations smallholders?
column12: farmers; aquaculture; farming systems; fisheries

column4: SSF Guidelines: Vital momentum for small-scale fishers
column5: With its Guidelines for Securing Sustainable Small-Scale Fisheries (SSF Guidelines), FAO has created a tool that is to help small-scale fisheries stakeholders empower themselves. Our authors describe its strengths and weaknesses and how it is being put into practice.
column7: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)
column12: fisheries; sustainable land management; farmers; aquaculture; development agencies

column4: Satellite data aid India’s fishermen for better livelihood
column5: Sailing out to sea in the morning and returning without a catch in the evening is now a thing of the past for many Indian fishermen. A satellite-based information system shows where they can find rich fishing grounds.
column12: fisheries; aquaculture; farming systems; farmers; natural resources management; geographical information systems

column4: Omena – small fish with a big potential for women’s business?
column5: It would be difficult to imagine the diet of the local consumers around Lake Victoria without the silver cyprinid. The small fresh water sardine also plays an important role in women’s participation in Kenya’s fishery sector. However, in spite of intensive efforts, there is still a long way to go before they have achieved an equal role in the value chain.
column12: fisheries; aquaculture; farming systems; women; farmers

column4: Mauritania: High tech to secure fish stocks
column5: Mauritania’s coastal waters are among the world’s richest fishing grounds. However, just as in many other countries around the globe, the sustainable use of this resource is under threat from illegal fishing and overfishing. KfW contributes to protecting the valuable fishing grounds with the aid of modern surveillance systems and rigorous conservation and species protection measures.
column12: fisheries; aquaculture; natural resources management; sustainable land management; water rights; riparian rights

column4: Captain Iglo mustn’t come to Africa!
column5: During the last few years, the donor community has increased its efforts to reduce the large amounts of fish lost in the distribution chain in artisanal fishery, an endeavour that ought to be welcomed in principle. However, focusing on one single solution, the development of an expensive cool chain and the supply of fresh or frozen fish, represents a massive interference with the traditional processing and distribution channels, with women being the main losers. Our author calls for more foresight in international co-operation.
column12: development; development agencies; fisheries; sustainable development; farmers; land investments; women; aquaculture; water rights; riparian rights

column4: Insects – a protein source with a recycling potential
column5: Like in other areas of livestock keeping, the growing demand for fish raises the question of how the feeding of animals can be maintained without competing with the provision of food for humans. The use of insect proteins could help save natural resources while simultaneously making use of organic waste.
column12: livestock; fisheries; land management; farming systems; food security; natural resources management; sustainable land management

column4: Hot topics in aquaculture research
column5: Experts agree that the rising demand for fish for human consumption cannot be met without a major expansion and sustainable intensification of aquaculture. Our WorldFish authors describe the areas in which research plays a particularly important role in this context.
column6: Michael Phillips; Sven Genschick; Andrew Thorne Lyman
column12: fisheries; food security; aquaculture; sustainable land management; riparian rights; research

column4: Biogas in Vietnam: Simple technology with a major impact
column5: Biogas in Vietnam is chiefly the story of the success of small domestic digesters. However, a feed-in tariff for electricity generated by biogas plants could soon lead to larger scale use of the technology, and so provide new sources of income for farmers.
column12: farming systems; farmers

column4: Processing tomatoes in Tanzania: a tale of seeds and ketchup
column5: An ingenious combination of plant breeding, contract farming and processing has enabled smallholder tomato growers to tap new markets in Tanzania’s Arusha Region. Two improved tomato cultivars released from AVRDC lines are at the centre of this success story.
column12: land management; farming systems; agriculture; agricultural land management

column4: Rural advisory services – back on the development agenda!
column5: Over the last few decades, the range of agricultural extension and advisory services as well as the notions of which tools and methods are most suitable have seen fundamental changes. Our authors give an overview of old and new approaches, showing what we already know and where there is a need for more information.
column12: agricultural land management; agriculture; rural development; development agencies

column4: Clarifying roles in extension processes
column5: Rural extension services are an extremely complex affair. This is due to the wide range of constellations in which farmers operate nowadays, and also to the large number of players who are active in advisory services, with their different tasks, values and mandates. With reference to Germany’s rural extension services, our author shows who is taking on which role and where conflicts might potentially arise.
column12: rural development; farmers; farming systems; development; development agencies

column4: Many actors, little coordination
column5: As with other countries, agricultural extension and advisory services (EAS) in Malawi are provided by public, private, and non-profit organisations. While it has become commonplace to refer to this collection of actors as a system, this claim is only valid in the loosest of terms, as many of the component parts do not functionally interact with others in an operational sense, tending rather to function as independent sub-networks within larger national, and international spheres of exchange. The potential for interaction and exchange between these component parts defines the potential for positive synergism, whereas the disconnect defines sources of inefficiencies, redundancies and conflict.
column12: agriculture; development agencies; development; sustainable development

column4: Sustainably financing extension services
column5: Providing extension and advisory services is expensive. There are salaries to be paid, transporta­tion and operational funds to be provided, buildings to be rented or built, demonstration plots to maintain, and continued education to be offered to the extension staff. And then there is the need to continually invest in an overall functioning agricultural innovation system with strong research and teaching institutions, enabling policies, as well as to make capital investments in rural infrastructure that will not only benefit the farming population. Where are these funds to come from, and will these expenditures pay off?
column12: sustainable development; land investments; development agencies; research; farming systems; rural development; local community; rural population

column4: Setting out from farmer realities
column5: The aim of the “Management advice for family farms” (MAFF) approach is to strengthen the abilities of farmers to manage their farms and improve their economic and social autonomy. In Francophone Africa, this holistic concept has been applied successfully for almost two decades.
column12: farmers; farming systems; agricultural land management; sustainable land management; development agencies

column4: Modern ICTs and rural extension: Have we reached the tipping point?
column5: Today, it would be difficult to imagine agricultural extension without modern information and communication technologies. What they can do, where they fit in, and where they reach their limits is shown in the following examples.
column7: Technical Centre for Agricultural and Rural Co-operation ACP-EU
column12: rural development; agriculture; agricultural land management; farming systems; farmers

column4: Biovision’s Farmer Communication Programme
column5: In many parts of Africa, formal education and training in agriculture is almost nonexistent. Swiss Biovision Foundation supports farmers via its Farmer Communication Programme. While it takes advantage of its close links with research institutions, the ideas and experiences of farmers also flow directly into its course contents.
column12: farmers; agriculture; agricultural land management; development agencies; research

column4: Farmer-to-farmer knowledge exchange
column5: Innovation takes place not only in laboratories, and disseminating knowledge need not depend on classrooms. The Cambodian GIZ project “Best Farmer 2012” is an example of how achievements of small-scale farmers can be appreciated and their co-farmers can simultaneously benefit from new insights.
column12: farmers; farming systems; agricultural land management; sustainable land management; development agencies

column4: From lab to field to market
column5: “There is plenty of innovation. The trick is to get it to the farmers,” it is often said when technology transfer to farmers, and smallholders in particular, is referred to. In addition to the financial resources, they often lack the knowledge needed to be able to benefit from the new technologies. The ‘whole value chain approach’ of the Africa Harvest organisation shows how technology transfer can work.
column6: Daniel Kamanga; Wangari Kiragu; Florence Wambugu
column12: farmers; farming systems; agricultural land management; sustainable land management; development agencies

column4: A (women)farmer-first approach – a case study from Papua New Guinea
column5: The Government extension services in Papua New Guinea (PNG) are weak. There is a general lack of money and staff, and the country has a poor infrastructure. Above all small-scale farmers in remote areas are left out of developments. This applies in particular to women farmers, despite their providing 85 per cent of the rural workforce.
column12: women; farmers; farming systems; agricultural land management; rural development

column4: Empowering rural women in India – it’s high time!
column5: Publicly elected women representatives in India ought to take advantage of their influence to defend women’s rights.
column12: rural development; rural population; women; gender equity in access to land; land rights

column4: The “Green charcoal chain”
column5: German Development Cooperation has developed an approach for the sustainable production of charcoal that has proved to have a considerable impact in Northern Madagascar. Since both environmental and socioeconomic aspects are addressed in a very effective way, this approach has high potential referring to global challenges such as land degradation, rural poverty and climate change.
column6:
Klaus Ackermann; Lisa Kirtz; Christian Andriamanantseheno; 
Steve Sepp
column12: development agencies; sustainable development; environment; sustainable land management; land degradation; poverty; rural development; climate change
column13: Land Stakeholders & Institutions; Land, Climate change & Environment

column4: “Zero pesticide” vegetables for the Indian market
column5: In the Karnataka state of India, the First Agro farm has more than 40 varieties of vegetables on sale, all of them free of chemical residues. Both hotels and restaurants as well as more and more retailers are appreciating the range of certified products from this young enterprise.
column12: farming systems; food security; agricultural land management; agriculture; farmers
